body:
I'm not sure that CoreFX has implemented it yet: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/api/system.xml#System_Xml

Leaving this open for someone else to validate though.

I just wanted to be documented.  I tried to use other assemblies under both Linux and Windows PowerShell 6.0.0.0-alpha.10 folder. But wasn't able to create a PowerShell object using New-Object.

I know that maybe this will be implemented sometime soon.

:)

@joeyaiello https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/tree/master/src/System.Xml.XmlDocument ??

@MaximoTrinidad you can only use classes that have been ported to .net Core. This is a _well_ [known issue](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/KNOWNISSUES.md#net-framework-vs-net-core-framework)

I'm also seeing similar results on OS X. I installed the MySql package via 'install-package', and then referenced the assembly using Add-Type. The MySql package came from: https://docs.efproject.net/en/latest/providers/mysql/

Add-Type didn't return any errors. However, when trying to reference that assembly it fails with:

```
New-Object : Cannot find type [MySql.Data.MySqlClient]: verify that the assembly containing this type is loaded.
At /Volumes/Main//development/scripts/test.ps1:53 char:15
+ $connection = New-Object MySql.Data.MySqlClient
+               ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidType: (:) [New-Object], PSArgumentException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : TypeNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.NewObjectCommand
```

Examining the $error stack trace ($error[0].Exception.StackTrace) returns this:

`System.Management.Automation.MshCommandRuntime.ThrowTerminatingError(ErrorRecord errorRecord) in /PowerShell/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/MshCommandRuntime.cs:line 2053`

```
$PSVersionTable                                                                                                                                                          
Name                           Value                                                                                                                                                      
----                           -----                                                                                                                                                      
PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha                                                                                                                                                
PSEdition                      Core                                                                                                                                                       
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}                                                                                                                                    
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0                                                                                                                                                    
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.10                                                                                                                                            
CLRVersion                                                                                                                                                                                
WSManStackVersion              3.0                                                                                                                                                        
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3                                                                                                                                                        
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1  
```

@jgraafstra You should have opened a new ticket. 

THIS ticket isn't really about loading, it's about types that were built-in in _Full .NET_ and are not in PowerShell Core (in this particular case, it should be fixable, since the XML classes are in CoreFX now).

However, _your_ problem is simply that you're doing it wrong ðŸ˜‰ 

`MySql.Data.MySqlClient` is a namespace, not a class.

First you _need to load [**all** of the **dependencies**](https://www.nuget.org/packages/MySql.Data.EntityFrameworkCore#dependencySets) for NetStandard_, including their dependencies (e.g. the dependencies of the [MySql.Data library](https://www.nuget.org/packages/MySql.Data/7.0.5-IR21), recursively. And there are _a lot_ of them.

Try checking to make sure you're not getting an **error** when you try to run `Add-Type` with -passthru ... run something like this:

``` posh
add-type -Path .\MySql.Data.dll -PassThru
```

If you get an error, then you can look at what assembly is missing:

``` posh
$Error[0].Exception.LoaderExceptions
```

To make it work, the simplest thing is to collect **all** the dependencies together in one folder.
You can do that like this:

``` posh
Install-Package MySql.Data.EntityFrameworkCore -RequiredVersion 7.0.5-IR21 -Destination .\MySql
Get-ChildItem .\MySql\*\lib\netstandard1.*\*.dll | Move-Item -Destination .\MySql -Force
Get-ChildItem .\MySql\ -Directory | Remove-Item -Recurse
```

Now that you have all the assemblies in the MySql folder, you can actually Add-Type successfully, and make a connection, like this:

``` posh
Add-Type -Path .\MySql\MySql.Data.EntityFrameworkCore.dll -PassThru
[MySql.Data.MySqlClient.MySqlConnection]::new("server=localhost; user id=root; password=admin; database=mydatabase");
```

Resolving as external given that this is a .NET Core problem. 

Also, @jaykul, I don't actually see any implementation in the folder you posted. They're just empty type forwarders
Good point @joeyaiello, the implementation is in /future (e.g. https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/future/src/System.Xml.XmlDocument/src/System/Xml/Dom/XmlDocument.cs )
